intro: Galium californicum subsp. luciense, commonly known as the Sierra bedstraw, is a low-growing herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender stems and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces clusters of tiny, white or pale yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors and stream banks. Its botanical structure supports its role in local ecosystems by providing habitat and nectar for pollinators.
